ResponsesInList.Text: I'm working on a tracking sheet that learners update each time they complete a criterion. I chose Database because it can be exported by the learner. Trying to put a form together that has the following layout: Title of activity Category 1 Criterion 1 date1, (date2, date3) comment Criterion 2 date1, (date2, date3) comment Category 2 Criterion 1 date1 (date2, date3) comment Criterion 2... The issue is that the date field is auto-populated with current date each time the Database is opened. As only one date field is necessary for the evidence, if a learner completes it with one date, the rest of the dates will be automatically be put in my Moodle regardless, which is not correct for the purposes of evidencing. Is there a way to make the date fields be all blank to start with or to have placeholders? Also, is it possible to export as pdf? That would be more suitable for exam bodies as evidence.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database - date field formatting
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know, there is no way to make the Date Field blank in Moodle Database Activity. One other way you might consider doing it is to have each entry contain just ONE Date, and then make a Radio Button or a Menu Field for the Category. Each user would just add a new record when they complete the step which would contain the date they completed that step. If you get clever with Groups (one user per group and separate groups), you can display each user's entries in the "List view" to see how many steps they have completed. Or you use the "Approval required" setting, and don't approve any entries to keep them "private" for students. You would need to filter by Student in order to see only one student's entries. You can use JavaScript in your template to "print" list views which would download as a PDF depending on your browser settings. There is a webinar and Moodle Academy course coming up in September on Moodle Database which may give you more ideas.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database - date field formatting
ResponsesInList.Text: I have encountered similar problems with the database activity. One possible solution, would be to set the date field up using a text field, rather than a date field. This isn't quite as attractive as you don't get the 'date picker' options, and you cannot do anything with the dates - e.g. sort by date (as people will enter them in all sorts of different formats), but it does overcome the issue of the field being populated when you don't want it to be.

Hi, In your template you have the Javascript included twice, remove one block. Also, remove the p element around the script tags. I always recommend to disable the code editor (uncheck the box) to have a plain text area for the template editing. Then you get the plain HTML and avoid errors when the editor does things (e.g. enclosing each paragraph into a p element) that are not preferred. What I also spot in your code is the missing id that is there by default and used in the javascript snippet. I guess your double square "How to pdf" is the variable placeholder that produces the link. In this case in your div element with the font-size or any other element, that contains the link to the pdf, add the id="defaulttemplate-single" attribute. The other solution would be going without the id attribute. In this case change the selector in the code from 

ResponsesInList.Title: Text fields of Database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: The text area allows you to specify a format. That can be HTML, Markup or Plaintext. As far as I know the format is not tied to the field definition, but to the entry when the content is added. In general, when a new dataset is entered by the user, the format is set automatically to HTML when the user has the Atto or TinyMCE as the default editor. When the user has the plain textarea displayed, the format selection appears and the user can choose what he might enter as content in that field. If your plugin never shows the "hidden" field to the user, then you also should be able to automatically set the format to plain text and fill the content.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database fo CPD and/or RPL
ResponsesInList.Text:
Kia ora team, I've created a Database that can be used for collecting CPD points/hours. Video demonstration (3 min; no sound; apologies for the amateur production!) Scenario A given number [n] of CPD hours/points are awarded per year; with [n] being the maximum
number of hours/points that can be awarded for the year/course. For
the purpose of the example courses, I have set that number at 20 CPD
hours/points per year. I am not sure if this is a realistic number but
it was (somewhat!) easier for me to do the maths in my head when I was
working things out. üòÖ Students upload evidence of their CPD to [a database activity in] the course. The course teacher views the CPD evidence and decides how many hours/points the CPD evidence is worth. The student can be awarded a badge/badges in 1 of 2 ways: One-off: The student receives a badge after completing 20 CPD hours/points. Iterative: The student receives a badge for every multiple of 5 CPD hours/points. (N.B. "Points" can be replaced with "hours" and "CPD" can be replaced with "RPL".) Here are the 2x ways, depending on how often you want to award people for their CPD points. One-off : i.e. 1x badge/permanent record for 20 points Iterative : (e.g.) 4x badges/permanent records, each for 5 points and accumulating to 20. Workflow: One-off How does it work? Student uploads evidence of their CPD to a database activity in the course. Each item is a separate entry into the database. The course teacher (or equivalent role) views the CPD evidence. They
mark it as approved and then give it a rating. The rating indicates how
many points CPD each evidence item (i.e. each database entry) is worth. Once 20 points is reached, the student is able to view and open a page
resource; opening the page resource triggers the badge being awarded.
(Done this way because badge criteria does not include grade.) OR Once 20 points is reached, the activity is considered complete and the badge is awarded automatically on activity completion. The student receives a badge. The badge reflects 20 CPD points. The
badge stays attached to the student profile regardless of any future
course enrolment or unenrolment. Reporting The teacher can view the gradebook to see how many points the student has accumulated. The student can view their gradebook to see how many points they have accumulated. Cons The maximum number of points is 20. If a student is awarded 10 + 5 + 8,
then they will only receive a maximum of 20 points. The additional 3
points beyond 20 will not be 'counted'. Workflow: Iterative How does it work? Student uploads evidence of their CPD to a database activity in the course. Each item is a separate entry into the database. The course teacher (or equivalent role) views the CPD evidence. They
mark it as approved and then give it a rating. The rating indicates how
many points CPD each evidence item (i.e. each database entry) is worth. Once 5 points are collected, the student is able to view and open a
page resource; opening the page resource triggers the badge being
awarded. (Done this way because badge criteria does not include grade.) The student receives a badge. The badge reflects 5 CPD points. The
badge stays attached to the student profile regardless of any future
course enrolment or unenrolment. Then, After 10 points are reached, the student is able to view and open
another page resource; opening the page resource triggers the badge
being awarded. The student receives another badge. The badge reflects (another) 5 CPD
points. The badge stays attached to the student profile regardless of
any future course enrolment or unenrolment. Then, the same kind of set-up for 15 points and 20 points. Reporting The teacher can view the gradebook to see how many points the student has received. The student can view their gradebook to see how many points they have accumulated. Pros Students can receive rewards more frequently. Cons Students have to click on the Page resource to receive their badge. Settings Both¬† "one-off" and "iterative" courses: Groups The course will have groups, in order for students to be able to only see their own database entries. You can auto create groups. Use the option Group # and the limit of 1 member per group. There
is a 3rd party plugin available for auto creation of groups on
enrolment, but I have not used it myself. Course settings Course name: CPD points 2024 Enable completion tracking: Yes Group mode: Separate groups Course Activities and Resources Database (and Pages for the "iterative" course) Database settings Name: My CPD points Entries Approval required: Yes Allow editing of approved entries: No Entries required before viewing: None Maximum number of entries: None Ratings Aggregate type: Sum of ratings Scale Type: Point Maximum grade: 20 Grade category: Uncategorised One-off: Grade to pass: 20.00 Iterative: Grade to pass: 0.00 Group mode Separate groups Add grouping restriction: Group: (Any group) Activity completion One-off: Completion tracking: Activity completion with pass grade Iterative: Completion tracking: Do not indicate activity completion Example fields Date completed (date) Upload evidence (file) Details (textarea field) Link to course or site ( URL field) *CPD can be replaced with RPL if necessary. Permission change Permission changes to Database activity "My CPD points": View the total rating you received (mod/data:viewrating): +Student Then, differences as follows: Settings: One-off Badge Name: "20 CPD points" Description: "The recipient has completed 20 CPD points." [Add anything that suits your course and users.] Criteria: Completion of Database activity Settings continued: Iterative Page x 4 (Page 1) Name:"Click here to be awarded your 5-point CPD badge" Page content: "Congratulations!" [Add further info if needed.] Page 1 Settings Restrict access Student must match the following Grade: My CPD points must be greater than and equal to 25% Hidden entirely Activity completion Show activity as complete when conditions are met: Student must view this activity to complete it. (Page 2, 3, 4) As for Page 1 BUT Restrict access Student must match the following Grade: My CPD points must be greater than and equal to 50% (Page 2) 75% (Page 3) 100% (Page 4) Hidden entirely Badges Badge 1 Name: "5 CPD points (1)" Description: "The recipient has completed 5 CPD points." [Add anything that suits your course and users.] Criteria: Completion of Page 1 "Click here to be awarded your 5-point CPD badge" Badge 2 Name: "5 CPD points (2)" Description: "The recipient has completed 5 CPD points." [Add anything that suits your course and users.] Criteria: Completion of Page 2 "Click here to be awarded your next 5-point CPD badge" Same for Badges 3, 4 - make sure they are connected to the correct Page. FAQ Why the additional step of the Page? Because a badge criterion can be activity completion but not grade. Why add Student to mod/data:viewrating? So that they can see the ratings they were given. Why groups? So that database entries can be only viewed by the student who made the entries. In order for the database entries to be rated, they must be approved. Why not display pages one by one? i.e. restrict access In case the student doesn't access the first badge before they are able to access the second badge. Could Teachers or Managers award the badges? If you want them to, yes, add them to the badge criteria. Why not have badges that are 5, 10, 15, 20 (rather than the proposed 5, 5, 5, 5)? Because Badge "5-point" and Badge "10-point "might look like a total of 15 points, when it is really a total of 10 points. A "20-point" badge could be a nice additional badge to round off the calendar year. Perhaps make the 20-point badge with no expiry date and the "5-point" badges could have expiry after a year. That way, badges don't become overwhelming or cluttered. Please add any comments or suggestions you have for improving this further. NgƒÅ mihi

ResponsesInList.Title: Open .PDF in New Tab from Database Activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello from Upstate NY USA - I have a database activity with over 3500 different types of documents (.PDF, .DOC, .MP4, etc.) .¬† One field in the database is used to upload a file.¬† Does anyone know of any code or setting I can add so that when a user selects a record that includes a .PDF document - this document opens in a new tab and DOES NOT download .¬† We know about browser and widows settings that can be adjusted, but not all users can adjust these settings.¬† We want to for the database to open this in a new tab and NOT download it at all. I don't see any settings on the field type that allows this. Thanks in advance. Lisa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open .PDF in New Tab from Database Activity
ResponsesInList.Text: This can be achieved creating a new tab with an iframe and put the binary data into the url ifself. The following code sample demonstrates this for PDF files only in the single view: document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", (event) => { document.querySelector('#defaulttemplate-single a.data-field-link').addEventListener('click', (ev) => { const url = ev.target.getAttribute('href'); if (url.match(/.*pdf$/i)) { ev.preventDefault(); With small modifications this can be adjusted to other file types as well and also in the list view. Basically after loading the DOMContentLoaded event attaches an event to the first Anchor element with the class "data-field-link" when the link is clicked. This attached function checks the suffix of the url and by this guessing what content type might be expected. For a pdf it fetches the content of the file, creates an iframe in a new window and adds the content via the src attribute. Here you have the chance instead of providing a url, use a base64 encoded string. That works also for other elemens such as images or anchor links when you want to force a download that otherwise would just be displayed in the browser. To make this work in the list view, two things need to be changed: * The query selector for fetching the Anchor links must not include #defaulttemplate-single * Fetch all Anchors with querySelectorAll() Best regards, Stephan

Here's a general approach to achieve this: 1. **Expose Data via API in Moodle:** - Set up an API within your Moodle instance to expose the data from the database activity. Moodle supports web services, including REST and SOAP protocols, which can be used to retrieve data programmatically. 2. **Access Moodle API from WordPress:** - In your WordPress website, you can use server -side programming languages like PHP or JavaScript to make HTTP requests to the Moodle API. Libraries like cURL (in PHP) or the Fetch API (in JavaScript) can be used to fetch data from Moodle's API endpoints. 3. **Parse and Display Data in WordPress:** - Once you retrieve the data from Moodle, you can parse it and display it on your WordPress site. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ideas for academic usage of database activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Databases can be used wherever you have structured data. Some use cases are: Collect measurement data When you give the students teacher assistent rights for the activity, they can than easily download the data themselves. Of course, if it is simple data, you can also use a collaborative spreadsheet with an office application for this use case. Build a ticket system for requests of students or staff. Manage equipment you want to lend out. Let students write structured reports about a certain topic. Use it for concept mapping. You need to install a plugin for that. Be aware that export of multimedia doesn't work with the database activity.

I didn't turn on comments, but you could if you want students to ask follow-up questions. I don't require approval of the entries, but if you are nervous about what might be posted, you can turn on "require approval." ResponsesInList.Title: Re: single header menu for database
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is the modified preset. Warning: When you go to edit the list template to see how it's made, over to the bottom left, click on, Disable editor. If you don't, and you use the editors, you will break the layout as it will save table info in the header that has to be in the footer for this to look right, when you are looking at the list view. In other words, it will turn the normally attached list view header , into a separate, un-attached row, above the rest of the list. Basically, what template is doing is putting the table start info in the Header area, and the table end info in the Footer area. You then add one table row in the header that contains table headers¬† with the column names and any formatting info you want, such as your use of strong. In the Repeated entry area, you define and format one table row with a definition of what goes in each cell or column. You should also add a More link in one cell. In this case I added it to the Noun cell. It makes it possible to go directly to a single record in, Single view. To make each row more compact, I have left off the examples and images. That's what the more link is for, to take you to the single view so you can see the whole entry. NOTE: You need to edit this preset as you do NOT make use of you CEFR checklist field. You have A1 hardcoded in so all entries are A1.

ResponsesInList.Title: Database Availability
ResponsesInList.Text: The database module provides 2 settings Available From and Available Until, which basically hide the activity from users if the date conditions aren't satisfied. This seems to duplicate the functionality of the (site-optional) Availability-Date conditions. Is there much objection to merging these 2 features so that the From - Until database setting is migrated to the core availability feature? It has been pointed out that availability is a feature that can be turned off at the site level. So I propose¬† to treat is as new feature on master, and to drop these 2 settings in favour of the Core Availability API. As part of the upgrade we could migrate the settings to the availability settings but it would require site admins to enable availability, but we should be able to highlight this requirement as part of the upgrade. My main reason for this is that it allows 2 ways for end-users to set up exactly the same behaviour, and for the sake of simplicity /reducing cognitive load, it seems that we should only offer one way of doing things. It was suggested some end-user feedback should be sought. Full details posted in https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-60927 M

ResponsesInList.Text: The Date field comes with some characters: 1. It pre-filled with the current Date. If you are requiring other Date, users have to manually alter it. 2. In Moodle2x, whenever you update your entry, the Date automatically adds one day. The bug has been fixed now, but if you are still in an old version, please have a double check. 3. When you export your entries to a spreadsheet, the¬†Date displays as a serial number, which you have to use a formula to convert it back. To work around these, you can use 'number', 'text' ¬†or 'dropdown' (preferred) ¬†field to produce Date/Month/Year, if you need them all. Then, you can 'require' your fields. HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Help with permissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Here's our need. In a database activity, some users (let's call them A users) must be able to add an only one entry and edit it afterwards. To do so, we set the max number of entries to one and we set "Entries required before viewing" to a greater number. This way, a user A can never see all of the entries. Then we have B users that sould be able to see all entries, but in read-only mode. We created a custom role copied from non-editing teacher, but we cannot find a way to allow them to see all entries without editing permissions. Any ideas? Fran√ßois

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help with permissions
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Fran√ßois, Sorry, you have to alter at least one permission . Part 1: Edit settings: 1. Approval required=Yes 2. As you did: 
```text
set the max number of entries = 1
```
 "Entries required before viewing" ¬†= None. 3. Remove #approve## AND ##disapprove## from templates. As long as you do NOT 'Approve an entry', nothing will be available for the 'A users' (Student role) to view, they can only work on the ONE they entered. Part 2: Creating a new role based on non-editing teacher Edit THIS Database permission only, move ONE dot: Manage entries=Prevent Part 3: Locally assign role to THIS Database activity only Assign 'B users' to non-editing teacher Now, B users should be able to see all entries, but in read-only mode. Do you want to stop B user to 'Add entry'? If so, you can set: Write entries=Prevent HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DB 2.5 issues vs. 2.8
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello. I haven't used 2.5 for a while but I think the delete option is the same as for later versions - and basically ¬†-you delete from the single view and not the list view. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DB 2.5 issues vs. 2.8
ResponsesInList.Text: You need at lease these tags for 'View list template' ##more## ##edit## ##delete## ##delcheck## & for 'View Single template' ##edit## ##delete## You can use these optional tags as well: ##approve## ##disapprove## ##export## ##timeadded## ##timemodified## ##user## ##comment## You can insert the 'Delete' icon anywhere, many times.

ResponsesInList.Title: DML function for list as field like GROUP_CONCAT, FOR XML PATH('') ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Occasionally, there is need to concatenate values from multiple rows in a query or subquery, like this query which shows which groups each user is in: SELECT firstname, GROUP_CONCAT(groupid) AS groups FROM mdl_user LEFT JOIN mdl_groups_members ON mdl_groups_members.userid=mdl_user.id GROUP BY userid; firstname groups Ray 1,2 Guest User NULL Note the "groups" field is a concatenation of a column from multiple rows. MySQL has the GROUP_CONCAT function for that. ¬†MS- SQL doesn't have a function designed for that purpose, so the common idiom is to use¬†FOR XML PATH(''). ¬†is there a Moodle DML function to do that in a database-neutral way? I've found many posts in this forum where people have been using GROUP_CONCAT, making their code not portable to Microsoft SQL and possibly others. ¬†If such a function doesn't exist in our library, should it be added, so people can use it rather than database specific code?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DML function for list as field like GROUP_CONCAT, FOR XML PATH('') ?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you think you need GROUP_CONCAT then it is probably a sign that you don't understand relational databases. GROUP_CONCAT is occasionally a useful hack in ad-hoc reports, but it should rarely be used for real.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DML function for list as field like GROUP_CONCAT, FOR XML PATH('') ?
ResponsesInList.Text: > If you think you need¬†GROUP_CONCAT¬†then it is probably a sign that you don't understand relational databases. I started to address that in my original post, and perhaps I should have. ¬†Certainly that's true when you WANT a relational data structure, such as in the business logic, so maybe 80% of the time that it's used, it shouldn't be. ¬†Then there's the other 20%, when it's not being used wrong. The other 20% of the time, when it's actually proper / okay to use in my opinion, fall into two categories, one when it's "acceptable", and one when it truly is the best way available.¬†Sometimes, it may be acceptable when both a) you're in the presentation layer and that's what you're going to end up with anyway, and also b) doing it in the query is ten times faster than calling a PHP function in a loop. ¬†A example of that would be as above, a list of users, one column of which is the groups they are in. ¬†If you're writing the UI page to show that (not a library for user info), I think that's acceptable. ¬†In that case, you WANT something easily human readable, you don't WANT a proper data structure any longer. Where it may be the best choice available would be if there were a class called user_list, which does not show the groups. ¬†You want to add a plugin to show the groups. Thankfully, class user_list does offer a method user_list->add_column() to add a cell to each row in the table. ¬†So easy enough to add the "user's groups" column, right? ¬†Except add_column() gets you one cell, for one value. ¬†The list of groups isn't a single value, so you can either a) have your plugin return the group list as one value or b) rewrite the exist user_list class to allow each cell to contain an array of values, which it will then concatenate in PHP, accomplishing precisely the same result with far more work. A particular instance of the above type of example that you are familiar with is¬†question_bank_column->get_required_fields() - it expects one field, so GROUP_CONCAT(tags) might be the best way to do it. ¬†The other option would be to get Tim involved in significant changes to how¬†question_bank works, just so you could have a column for "Used by these quizzes", or "has these tags". Wow I was long-winded in this post, but I don't feel like editing it to be shorter.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: One Database connection to other IP's
ResponsesInList.Text: You mean that you the database server is on a different server to the Moodle web server? Put the IP address in $CFG->dbhost in config.php (definitely not 'localhost'). When you create the username and password you will have to be careful with the GRANT command. It needs to reflect the IP or name of the Moodle server. E.g. GRANT ...... on moodle.* to moodleuser@192.168.1.99 ..... You also need to have networking enabled in MySQL - if it is already accessed from other machines then you won't have to worry about that. It's usually that GRANT command that's the problem with MySQL and there are some settings in my.cnf that can trip you up. More info: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/access-denied.html

ResponsesInList.Title: record id hack
ResponsesInList.Text: In order to link together two database activities I use the moodle internal record id. In order to display this id on the screen I made a very simple hack that adds a tag to the template editor. Basically the hack makes ##mdlid## be replaced by the record id as stored in the moodle database (much like ##timemodified## works). This is a quick and dirty hack, I know, but it might prove useful to some of you. Here she goes: In mod/data/templates.php around line 236 add: echo '<optgroup label="'.get_string('other', 'data').'">'; echo '<option value="##mdlid##">'.'record id'. ' - ##mdlid##</option>'; echo '<option value="##timeadded##">'.get_string('timeadded', 'data'). ' - ##timeadded##</option>'; In mod/data/lib.php around line 953 add: $patterns[] = '##timemodified##'; $replacement [] = userdate($record->timemodified); $patterns[] = '##mdlid##';

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tables descriptions and ERM diagram ?
ResponsesInList.Text: You might like to create your own diagram (The give a fish/teach to fish type scenario). The following commentary may be useful. moodle_er_diagram Creating an ER Diagram from the log generated at install time. Note that some of the table relationships in Moodle are not strictly relational, i.e. some tables may have multiple value fields and there may be missing primary/foreign key relationships. This will result in a diagram where a table has no link to any other table. However this process may still result in a diagram that is useful to understand the database design. This was done on a Windows/Xampp machine. And MySQL Workbench 5.1.18 Don't do it on any system with important data, it involves truncating (deleting all records from the log) This assumes the use of the My SQL database. It was done using the MyISAM back end. I believe it would work with innodb. Ensure that the MySQL install is set to write logs to a table rather than a file with the following line in the my.ini file log-output=TABLE Change to directory root of install lib\xmldb\classes\generators Edit XMLDBGenerator.php Change Line 66 var $foreign_keys=false; to read var $foreign_keys=true; Do a fresh unattended install of Moodle up to the point where you are asked for the admin password. Then stop login to mysql from the command prompt issue the following commands use mysql truncate general_log; select argument from general_log where argument like '%create table%' into outfile 'moodle.sql' LINES TERMINATED BY '\r'; on my xampp install the file was output to the directory server \mysql\data\mysql load the generated file into an editor do a replace operation to find every incidence of CREATE TABLE and replace with ; CREATE TABLE This will ensure that every statement is executed. The import into MySQL workbench using the File/Import Reverse Engineer Mysql Create Script In Workbench select Model/Add Diagram. Select all tables from the Catalog list and drag onto the diagram.Select arrange/Autolayout and then wait. With around 200 tables, it might take a while to layout the diagram. Even then you will probably want to move things around to make it easier to understand.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Odg: Re: Tables descriptions and ERM diagram ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, Moodle database structure is defined in XML files. These contain comments. There is functionality to compile these comments into HTML documentation. For example: 1. Go to http://qa.moodle.net/ 2. Follow the instructions to log in as admin. 3. In the Settings block, do Site Administration -> Development -> XMLDB editor. 4. Click the [Doc] link at the top. With the code of Moodle can display all the data that I want (details, templates, etc ...). ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Take the fields of a record in a table
ResponsesInList.Text: Domenico - You need to understand the relationships between mdl_data, mdl_data_fields, mdl_data_content, and perhaps mdl_data_records. I will simplify the notations here to give you an idea data.id->>data_fields.dataid (an instance of a database activity module can have one or more fields joined by the respective id and dataid fields), data.id->>data_records.dataid (an instance of a database activity module can have one or more records added to it), data_fields.id,data_records.id->data_content.fieldid,data_content.recordid (the content is stored combining the record and field ids - in other words the content for a particular entry's particular field. So, I would start by creating something like: $data = get_record('data','id',$dataid); // where $dataid is the id of database activity module you are working on $datarecord = get_record('data_records','dataid',$data->id,'userid',$USER->id); //get this user's entry $fieldidname = get_record('data_fields','dataid',$data->id,'name','Name'); //get the field record for the Name field in this database $fieldidage = get_record('data_fields','dataid',$data->id,'name','Age'); //get the field record for the Age field in this database $datamyname = get_record('data_content','fieldid',$fieldidname->id,'recordid',$datarecord->id); // get the content record for the Name field by the current user $datamyage = get_record('data_content','fieldid',$fieldidage->id,'recordid',$datarecord->id); // get the content record for the Name field by the current user $myname = $datamyname->content; //get the actual data from the content record $myage = $datamyage->content; //get the actual data from the content record This is obviously not the prettiest way of getting at the data but I hope that it helps to illustrate how the data is stored. Please note that I have not tested this code as it was written solely for illustrative purposes so there may be mistakes in it. In summary, you need to have the recordid and the fieldid in order to get to the content. Let me know if this is helpful to you. Peace - Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm trying to run a query directly on the Moodle database.¬† I want to return all the current students of a course.¬† I can see students are associated with a course through the mdl_course_display table, but this returns old students who were previously associated with the course too.¬† How do I filter these out so that only the current students remain? Many thanks to anyone who can help! Bryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Bryan, The table you are referring to mdl_course_display isn't used to display enrolments. It's used to remember the display state for the course, for example user 123 on course 2345 may have topic 2 visible and all the rest collapsed. An entry is only written to this table when a user visits a course on which they are enrolled. When they are unenroled the record still remains as it's nothing to do with enrolments and used purely for the display. I think what you are trying to do is determine course enrolments. The table you need to be looking at (I think) is mdl_role_assignments. Regards, Lewis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Lewis. I found the solution (courtesy of the genius of Enovation, Dublin), if anyone else is having the same problem - here's the SQL : SELECT u.username, c.fullname FROM mdl_user u, mdl_role_assignments r, mdl_course c, mdl_context t WHERE t.instanceid = c.id AND u.deleted != -1 AND r.contextid = t.id AND r.userid = u.id AND r.roleid = 5 AND c.id = {course code id you want to query}

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Querying current students
ResponsesInList.Text: Not complete Genius. Adding AND t.contextlevel = 50 is necessary. Also, roleid 5 = student is an assumption you should check.

ResponsesInList.Text: A moodle module is PHP code! And I am not talking about some third-party plugin. The gradebook is an integral part of Moodle, and it can export data in a variety of formats. ResponsesInList.Title: How to replicate a database structure
ResponsesInList.Text: Log in as admin or teacher to the course containing the db. Use Backup (in the Administration block) to backup the database. You will need to back it up with user data (which I know is not what you want - but I believe or hope that folks are working on resolving that problem). You can Restore the resulting archive to another location, and then remove the user records from that restored instance (I know - laborious if you have a lot of user records). If you then Backup that new instance (which has no user records), again specifying that it's to be backed up with user data, you'll have a backup which contains just field and templates.

ResponsesInList.Title: Feature ideas for the Database module.
ResponsesInList.Text: I was chatting to some folk here who'd be looking at the Database module and found that it didn't do quite what they needed. I'm posting their requirements here for reference really just so that if anybody just happens to be looking for ways to improve the module at any point, they've got the information. Also, do let me know if any of this is actually possible already! These are the important issues: (1) Data input needs to be verified by user defined criteria.¬† For example if a student inputs a date of an observation, I want to check that the date is in the past.¬† I also need to be able to check that values are in certain ranges. (2) I need to be able to read the data from a program or application.¬† This could be achieved in different ways.¬† A live link to the actual table using ODBC.¬† But perhaps a simpler solution would be an automatic download from the table every 24 hours as a comma separated file, or some variation of this (i.e. just download records that have been added). (3) Moodle needs to be able to display ‚Äòlive‚Äô data.¬† For example I should be able to read my data table, create a graph or a map, copy that graph or map to some disk area which Moodle polls at least once a day and updates its website, so the students see the results of their data collection. (4) A nice touch would be entering data by clicking on images too. (2) and (3) would enable me to provide an autonomous solution.¬† I would write a program which I would schedule to run once a day, it would read the latest data, update its map or whatever, copy it to the Moodle update area and the students would see the results.¬† I really don‚Äôt think anything less than this cuts it.¬† Just imagine a long running project that collects data from all over the UK.¬† Can we really imagine that people are going to be happy to copy and paste data out of Moodle into their application and then go back into Moodle to upload some file.¬† I don‚Äôt think that will work in the long run.

ResponsesInList.Title: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any way to put entries the database and then search the entries in a "fuzzy" manner so that you get matches that are similar and not just matches that are identical (as in a google search, etc.)?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: Doesn't anybody have any idea about this at all?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: After doing a great deal of research it is gradually dawning on my just how complex my question was . . .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fuzzy Searches
ResponsesInList.Text: The best way is to avoid using a database at all and instead use search engine technology, as seen in Google and Yahoo. The best open source contender is Lucene , a java application that is widely ported and integrated with other languages. At the moment PHP seems to be lagging behind other languages in their support for this technology, but the recent emergence of 2 seperate Web Service-enabled Lucene search engines may be the key to breaking through this barrier (though sadly this probably rules it out for most people running Moodle on standard commercial hosting, or at least increases the complexity greatly). Lucence Web Service API solr The second is more recent and more advanced. The most readable introduction to the relevant technology is the On Search series written by Tim Bray . However, given the lack of PHP-Lucene integration, and the portablity needs of Moodle it seems likely that lowest common denominator SQL methods will be the best available technology for the moment.

I'd already tried to find something like Lucene but it is quite difficult wading through loads of stuff when you don't really know what you are looking for. It was quite an education though.
